articles.headline: Tuition Refunds, but Not Quite on Equal Terms
articles.snippet: Sallie Mae offers tuition refund insurance policies for students who become ill and must withdraw from college, but they pay out only 75 percent if the cause is mental illness.
articles.abstract: Sallie Mae offers tuition refund insurance policies for students who become ill and must withdraw from college, but they pay out only 75 percent if the cause is mental illness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sallie Mae wants to be a cradle-to-grave resource, helping parents save for their children’s college educations until they’re 18, then lending students money for tuition, helping them save for their own children’s bills and so on until they’re great-grandparents.

articles.headline: Central Bank May Be Winner in Europe’s Debt Talks
articles.snippet: Jean-Claude Trichet, the central bank president, appeared to have won on getting governments to reclaim the task of preventing collapse of the Greek economy.
articles.abstract: Jean-Claude Trichet, the central bank president, appeared to have won on getting governments to reclaim the task of preventing collapse of the Greek economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and other European leaders appeared to act in defiance of the European Central Bank when they insisted that banks contribute to the latest rescue plan for Greece. But the central bank president, Jean-Claude Trichet, may consider himself the real winner of the week.

articles.headline: Players in a Greek Drama
articles.snippet: The power of Fitch, Standard & Poor’s or Moody’s Investors Service to cut a government’s debt rating has given the agencies a pivotal role in the worldwide financial drama.
articles.abstract: The power of Fitch, Standard & Poor’s or Moody’s Investors Service to cut a government’s debt rating has given the agencies a pivotal role in the worldwide financial drama.
articles.lead_paragraph: This summer, David Riley is one of the world’s most powerful financial analysts.

articles.headline: Dodd-Frank Backers Clash With Regulator
articles.snippet: Consumer advocates criticize John Walsh, acting comptroller of the currency, for trying to soften a wide range of provisions of the financial regulatory overhaul.
articles.abstract: Consumer advocates criticize John Walsh, acting comptroller of the currency, for trying to soften a wide range of provisions of the financial regulatory overhaul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John Walsh voiced the frustrations of many bankers when he warned in a speech last month that federal regulators were not paying attention to the cumulative impact of new rules and restrictions, jeopardizing the ability of banks to support economic growth.

articles.headline: In Greek Pact, Compromises and Intrigues
articles.snippet: The latest bailout in the Greek saga has the elements of familiar European intrigue: private meetings, cries of protest and then a deal as markets veer toward panic.
articles.abstract: The latest bailout in the Greek saga has the elements of familiar European intrigue: private meetings, cries of protest and then a deal as markets veer toward panic.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The latest bailout in the Greek rescue has all the elements of what is fast becoming almost commonplace European intrigue.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Revamped Humvee Draws Military’s Eye
articles.snippet: Tests show that Humvees with a new chimney could provide as much protection as some of the heavier, and more costly, mine-resistant vehicles.
articles.abstract: Tests show that Humvees with a new chimney could provide as much protection as some of the heavier, and more costly, mine-resistant vehicles.
articles.lead_paragraph: An innovative chimney to vent blasts from buried bombs could make the Humvee safer and bring the most popular military vehicle since the Jeep back from the sidelines in Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Worthy Rivals for the Crown in Smartphones
articles.snippet: Can Apple retain its dominance after ending the iPhone’s exclusivity to AT&T? A Verizon subscriber compares the packaging and content of rival devices.
articles.abstract: Can Apple retain its dominance after ending the iPhone’s exclusivity to AT&T? A Verizon subscriber compares the packaging and content of rival devices.
articles.lead_paragraph: First sold to the public just four years ago, the Apple iPhone melded the vast potential of the Internet with a multimedia player, a still and video camera, e-mail, texting, instant messaging, social networking and other applications — now 425,000 and counting — into one elegant, easy-to-use touch-screen package. And it makes voice calls. Rarely has one device so upended a market.

articles.headline: In 3 Countries, Challenging the Vatican on Female Priests
articles.snippet: Incidents on three continents raise anew the issue of the ordination of women and married men.
articles.abstract: Incidents on three continents raise anew the issue of the ordination of women and married men.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 150 Roman Catholic priests in the United States have signed a statement in support of a fellow cleric who faces dismissal for participating in a ceremony that purported to ordain a woman as a priest, in defiance of church teaching.

articles.headline: Oslo Suspect Wrote of Fear of Islam and Plan for War
articles.snippet: The man charged with the attacks in Oslo that killed at least 92 people left behind a detailed manifesto calling for a Christian war to defend Europe against the threat of Muslim domination, officials said.
articles.abstract: The man charged with the attacks in Oslo that killed at least 92 people left behind a detailed manifesto calling for a Christian war to defend Europe against the threat of Muslim domination, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO — The Norwegian man charged Saturday with a pair of attacks in Oslo that killed at least 92 people left behind a detailed manifesto outlining his preparations and calling for a Christian war to defend Europe against the threat of Muslim domination, according to Norwegian and American officials familiar with the investigation.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Lawmakers Renew Push for Deal on Cutting Deficit
articles.snippet: Hoping to reassure markets, Congressional leaders raced to reach a new deficit-reduction deal that Speaker John A. Boehner said could cut $3 trillion to $4 trillion.
articles.abstract: Hoping to reassure markets, Congressional leaders raced to reach a new deficit-reduction deal that Speaker John A. Boehner said could cut $3 trillion to $4 trillion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite growing fears that world markets might react negatively to a breakdown in the federal budget negotiations, Congressional leaders clashed Saturday night as they tried to reach a new deficit-reduction agreement that Speaker John A. Boehner told colleagues could cut $3 trillion to $4 trillion in spending over 10 years.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Hulu, Billed as Tomorrow’s TV, Looks Boxed In
articles.snippet: Questions about how to make money pose a challenge to the innovative Web site’s future and eventual buyer.
articles.abstract: Questions about how to make money pose a challenge to the innovative Web site’s future and eventual buyer.
articles.lead_paragraph: PICTURE this: TV anyway, anywhere.

articles.headline: China to Wall Street: The Side-Door Shuffle
articles.snippet: A number of Chinese businesses have gone public in the United States without some usual hurdles.
articles.abstract: A number of Chinese businesses have gone public in the United States without some usual hurdles.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dalian, China
articles.byline: By David Barboza and Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: The Banks Still Want a Waiver
articles.snippet: Could an eventual settlement of the foreclosure mess give banks a shield against future lawsuits?
articles.abstract: Could an eventual settlement of the foreclosure mess give banks a shield against future lawsuits?
articles.lead_paragraph: HOW should banks atone for those foreclosure abuses — all the robo-signing and shoddy recordkeeping that jettisoned so many people from their homes?

articles.headline: Ex-Schools Chief Emerges as Unlikely Murdoch Ally
articles.snippet: Joel I. Klein, who joined the News Corporation this year and had opposed a probe into hacking, is now leading it.
articles.abstract: Joel I. Klein, who joined the News Corporation this year and had opposed a probe into hacking, is now leading it.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by  Jeremy W. Peters,  Michael Barbaro and  Javier C. Hernandez.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters, Michael Barbaro and Javier C. Hernández

articles.headline: For Young Campers, Island Turned Into Fatal Trap
articles.snippet: The shooting suspect apparently saw the embodiment of his hatred for immigrants and political correctness at a retreat for the liberal elite.
articles.abstract: The shooting suspect apparently saw the embodiment of his hatred for immigrants and political correctness at a retreat for the liberal elite.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO — It has been a rite of passage for Norway’s liberal elite for decades: a summer camp set on a verdant Nordic isle called Utoya, where this week hundreds of young people gathered to meet government ministers, dive into election strategy sessions and maybe find a little summer romance.

articles.headline: Pakistan Spies on Its Diaspora, Spreading Fear
articles.snippet: American officials say the Pakistani spy agency aims to exert influence over lawmakers, stifle dialogue critical of Pakistan’s military and blunt the influence of India.
articles.abstract: American officials say the Pakistani spy agency aims to exert influence over lawmakers, stifle dialogue critical of Pakistan’s military and blunt the influence of India.
articles.lead_paragraph: The article is by  Mark Mazzetti,  Eric Schmitt and  Charlie Savage.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt and Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Rival Debt Plans Being Assembled by Party Leaders
articles.snippet: House Speaker John A. Boehner and Senator Harry Reid were preparing separate backup plans to raise the debt ceiling after leaders were unable to end a standoff over the budget.
articles.abstract: House Speaker John A. Boehner and Senator Harry Reid were preparing separate backup plans to raise the debt ceiling after leaders were unable to end a standoff over the budget.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House speaker, John A. Boehner, and the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, were preparing separate backup plans to raise the nation’s debt ceiling on Sunday after they and the White House were unable to form a bipartisan plan that would end an increasingly grim standoff over the federal budget.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Europe’s Troubled Economies Join the Rescue Team
articles.snippet: Italy and Spain are major guarantors, but they may be next in line for aid if Europe’s debt crisis deepens.
articles.abstract: Italy and Spain are major guarantors, but they may be next in line for aid if Europe’s debt crisis deepens.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Can a bailout fund whose backers include some of the countries it may be called upon to bail out really succeed? That’s the question being asked by skeptical investors about the European Financial Stability Facility — the rescue fund of 440 billion euros, or $632 billion, that is being given new, amplified powers to help the euro zone end the sovereign debt crisis.

articles.headline: In China, Apple Finds a Sweet Spot
articles.snippet: Must-have gadgets are causing a stir, with stores packed and inventory sparse.
articles.abstract: Must-have gadgets are causing a stir, with stores packed and inventory sparse.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — A year after opening a flagship store here, Apple has a problem that any retailer would envy: the huge 16,000-square-foot space is already too small.

articles.headline: With Fan at the Helm, Marvel Safely Steers Its Heroes to the Screen
articles.snippet: Kevin Feige, president of Marvel Studios and a comics enthusiast, has been on a box office tear over the last few years.
articles.abstract: Kevin Feige, president of Marvel Studios and a comics enthusiast, has been on a box office tear over the last few years.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Power in Hollywood is usually telegraphed in the least subtle way possible. People hopscotch to meetings by helicopter (Ryan Kavanaugh of Relativity Media), camp courtside at Lakers games (Jeffrey Katzenberg) and build HBO series around their antics (the superagent Ari Emanuel).

articles.headline: Scandal Splinters a Family Business
articles.snippet: The phone hacking scandal could threaten Rupert Murdoch’s plans of succession and his family’s control over News Corporation.
articles.abstract: The phone hacking scandal could threaten Rupert Murdoch’s plans of succession and his family’s control over News Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The News Corporation, the global enterprise controlled by Rupert Murdoch, has a history of living by its own rules and operating beyond consequence. That ended last week.

articles.headline: With Washington at Impasse, Worry Over Investor Reaction
articles.snippet: With the debt limit talks at a stalemate, Wall Street and Washington have turned their attention to a critical question: How long will investors give them?
articles.abstract: With the debt limit talks at a stalemate, Wall Street and Washington have turned their attention to a critical question: How long will investors give them?
articles.lead_paragraph: As Congress and President Obama failed yet again to break their stalemate over the debt limit, Wall Street and Washington turned their attention to a critical question: How long will investors give them?
articles.byline: By Louise Story and David Kocieniewski

articles.headline: Killings in Norway Spotlight Anti-Muslim Thought in U.S.
articles.snippet: The man accused of the killing spree in Norway was deeply influenced by anti-Muslim bloggers and right-wing activists in the U.S., lacing his 1,500-page manifesto with quotations from them.
articles.abstract: The man accused of the killing spree in Norway was deeply influenced by anti-Muslim bloggers and right-wing activists in the U.S., lacing his 1,500-page manifesto with quotations from them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The man accused of the killing spree in Norway was deeply influenced by a small group of American bloggers and writers who have warned for years about the threat from Islam, lacing his 1,500-page manifesto with quotations from them, as well as copying multiple passages from the tract of the Unabomber.

articles.headline: New Loyalties and Old Feuds Collide in Syria
articles.snippet: Syria is awash in stories of solidarity, but older forces — geography, class and, in particular, religious sect — can also tear it apart.
articles.abstract: Syria is awash in stories of solidarity, but older forces — geography, class and, in particular, religious sect — can also tear it apart.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOMS, Syria — On the birth of his daughter this month, a young activist in this central city bestowed on her a name that had little resonance until not so long ago. Dara’a, he called her, the namesake of the southern Syrian town where the antigovernment uprising began.

articles.headline: Room to Rent, via the Web
articles.snippet: Airbnb, a San Francisco-based company that says it handles 10,000 guests a night, is at the center of a boom in start-ups that are creating a market for places to stay.
articles.abstract: Airbnb, a San Francisco-based company that says it handles 10,000 guests a night, is at the center of a boom in start-ups that are creating a market for places to stay.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Lisa Marion’s roommates moved out of her apartment in Toronto in February, she scrambled to find replacements. But instead of finding one or two, she found 30.
